title: Numerical Analysis of a PCF-SPR Sensor for Adulterant Detection in Milk
authors: Emranul Haque, Abdullah Al Noman, S. M. Rakibul Islam, Kh Shahriya Zaman, Feroz Ahmed
abstract: We propose a novel photonic crystal fiber-based surface plasmon resonance sensor for the simultaneous detection of milk adulterants, which achieved wavelength sensitivities of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4878.05 ~\text{nm} /$</tex> RIU for fat adulteration, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{4 2 5 5. 3 2 ~ n m} / \text{R I U}$</tex> for melamine.

title: Exploration of Teaching Reform in the Course of Intelligent Prediction in the Information Age
authors: Jian Ma, Yujie Cheng, Hualiang Wang, Hongmei Liu, Laifa Tao, Chen Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: "Intelligent Prediction in the Information Era" is a specialized general education course designed for undergraduates. This study focuses on the teaching needs and issues in the current teaching model of this course, conducting an in-depth investigation from three aspects: teaching content, teaching methods, and evaluation system. There search develops a set of teaching content that integrates and correlates intelligent prediction knowledge across multiple disciplines for undergraduates and proposes a new syllabus. Furthermore, it explores teaching methods that inspire students' active and innovative research thinking and designs assessment standards to guide students in actively exploring intelligent prediction techniques. There search findings provide significant reference value for the reform and innovation of teaching models and methods in undergraduate specialized general education courses.

title: Tunable Metasurface Unit for Retroreflection and Radar Cross-Section Control
authors: Yi-Bing Xiao, Yue-Yi Zhang, Yong-Qiang Liu, Chao-Hai Du
abstract: This paper presents a metasurface unit designed for efficient retroreflection control, consisting of a three-layer structure with a metallic ring that can rotate to adjust the reflection amplitude and phase. The unit allows precise control over the reflection properties of the metasurface. At 14 GHz, the reflection amplitude of the cross-polarized wave varies between 0 and 0.95, exhibiting a clear binary phase characteristic with a phase difference of 180°. The arrays of these units are simulated, and the backscatter Radar Cross Section (RCS) values are analyzed for different rotation angles (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha= \pm 45^{\circ}, \alpha= \pm 61.2^{\circ}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha= \pm 16.2^{\circ}$</tex>) and corresponding amplitudes (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1,0.8$</tex>, and 0.5). The results demonstrate that controlling the rotation angle of the units enables precise adjustment of the backscatter intensity, offering potential for advanced electromagnetic wave manipulation.

title: Computation Capacity Maximization for Pinching Antennas-Assisted Wireless Powered MEC Systems
authors: Peng Liu, Meng Hua, Guangji Chen, Xinyi Wang, Zesong Fei
abstract: In this paper, we investigate a novel wireless powered mobile edge computing (MEC) system assisted by pinching antennas (PAs), where devices first harvest energy from a base station and then offload computation-intensive tasks to an MEC server. As an emerging technology, PAs utilize long dielectric waveguides embedded with multiple localized dielectric particles, which can be spatially configured through a pinching mechanism to effectively reduce large-scale propagation loss. This capability facilitates both efficient downlink energy transfer and uplink task offloading. To fully exploit these advantages, we adopt a non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) framework and formulate a joint optimization problem to maximize the system’s computational capacity by jointly optimizing device transmit power, time allocation, PA positions in both uplink and downlink, and radiation control. To address the resulting non-convexity caused by variable coupling, we develop an alternating optimization algorithm that integrates particle swarm optimization (PSO) with successive convex approximation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed PA-assisted design substantially improves both energy harvesting efficiency and computational performance compared to conventional antenna systems.

title: Road Extraction: An Improved U-Net Based Approach with Attention Mechanisms and Multi-Scale Fusion for Satellite Imagery
authors: Long Yu, Pinneng Zhang, Yuying Miao, Wang Man
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: Road extraction from satellite images is crucial for urban planning, transportation management, and disaster response. Traditional methods struggle with challenges such as varying road widths, occlusions, and background noise. This paper proposes an improved U-Net architecture that integrates channel and spatial attention modules between the encoder and decoder to enhance feature capture at road edges and intersections. Additionally, a multi-scale feature fusion strategy, inspired by D-LinkNet, addresses road width variability and noise interference. Drawing from Transformer-based attention mechanisms, the model ensures robust performance on small-scale datasets. Experiments on the Kaggle Road Segmentation Data dataset demonstrate superior results, achieving an IoU of 76.3% and F1 score of 76.4%, outperforming the baseline UNet by 5.2% in IoU and recent state-of-the-art models. Ablation studies confirm the contributions of each module, while cross-scene and noise robustness analyses highlight the model's generalization. This approach provides a lightweight, efficient solution for high-precision road extraction in remote sensing applications.

title: Deep Learning-Aided Polar Coded Modulation
authors: Yi-Wei Lu, Shan Lu, Takaya Yamazato, Zsu-Kai Lin, Yeong-Luh Ueng
abstract: In bit-interleaved coded modulation (BICM) systems, the conventional demodulation assumes equal a priori probabilities for all constellation points, inherently leading to performance degradation. To enhance the performance of BICM, BICM with iterative decoding (BICM-ID) was developed. We aim to apply neural networks to BICM to achieve joint modulation and decoding and overcome the performance degradation, with the goal of surpassing the performance of BICM-ID. In this paper, we propose a neural demodulator that incorporates an additional probability layer to mitigate performance degradation in BICM systems. Furthermore, we introduce Joint Model-1, which integrates this neural demodulator with a belief propagation (BP) decoder for 16-QAM polar-coded BICM. To further improve performance, we use Joint Model-1 as a pre-trained model and extend it by adding an additional dense layer, resulting in Joint Model-2. Experimental results show that Joint Model-2 surpasses both BICM and BICM-ID systems under Ungerboeck labeling.

title: Probabilistic Line-of-Sight Based Non-Orthogonal Channels Access: Modeling and Optimization
authors: Liwei Gu, Lifeng Wang, Dianxiong Liu, Yang Cao
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the problem of scene modeling and distributed channel selection optimization with non-orthogonal channels. Aiming at scene modeling, we propose a probabilistic line-of-sight (LoS) communication model, which overcomes the limitation of fixed communication distance in current research on non-orthogonal channels through taking into account the attenuation of the communication distance due to path loss. To deal with the optimization problem of channel selection, an improved Max-logit learning algorithm is proposed to optimize the distributed channel selection strategy, which reduces system interference and improves network throughput through a heterogeneous learning rate and appropriate the unaltered action probability. Experimental results validate that the proposed algorithm provides a significant reduction in cumulative interference, as well as improves spectrum utilization and network throughput. In addition, it can adapt to communication requirements more efficiently than traditional centralized and other distributed access algorithms, thus ensuring stable system performance in dense user environments.

title: Chartwin: a Case Study on Channel Charting-aided Localization in Dynamic Digital Network Twins
authors: Lorenzo Cazzella, Francesco Linsalata, Mahdi Maleki, Damiano Badiniy, Matteo Matteucci, Umberto Spagnolini
abstract: Wireless communication systems can significantly benefit from the availability of spatially consistent representations of the wireless channel to efficiently perform a wide range of communication tasks. Towards this purpose, channel charting has been introduced as an effective unsupervised learning technique to achieve both locally and globally consistent radio maps. In this letter, we propose Chartwin, a case study on the integration of localization-oriented channel charting with dynamic Digital Network Twins (DNTs). Numerical results showcase the significant performance of semi-supervised channel charting in constructing a spatially consistent chart of the considered extended urban environment. The considered method results in ≈ 4.5 m localization error for the static DNT and ≈ 6 m in the dynamic DNT, fostering DNT-aided channel charting and localization.

title: Data-driven Method to Ensure Cascade Stability of Traffic Load Balancing in O-RAN Based Networks
authors: Mengbang Zou, Yun Tang, Weisi Guo
abstract: Load balancing in open radio access networks (O-RAN) is critical for ensuring efficient resource utilization, and the user’s experience by evenly distributing network traffic load. Current research mainly focuses on designing load-balancing algorithms to allocate resources while overlooking the cascade stability of load balancing, which is critical to prevent endless handover. The main challenge to analyse the cascade stability lies in the difficulty of establishing an accurate mathematical model to describe the process of load balancing due to its nonlinearity and high-dimensionality. In our previous theoretical work, a simplified general dynamic function was used to analyze the stability. However, it is elusive whether this function is close to the reality of the load balance process. To solve this problem, 1) a data-driven method is proposed to identify the dynamic model of the load balancing process according to the real-time traffic load data collected from the radio units (RUs); 2) the stability condition of load balancing process is established for the identified dynamics model. Based on the identified dynamics model and the stability condition, the RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) can control RUs to achieve a desired load-balancing state while ensuring cascade stability.

title: Traffic-Aware Cellular User Association via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yiming Zhang, Dongning Guo
abstract: The increasing density of cellular access points (APs) and user devices necessitates efficient user association strategies to balance traffic loads and ensure quality of service. This paper presents a traffic-aware user association framework leveraging multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), where APs cooperatively learn association policies based on network conditions and traffic demands. A dual-timescale architecture is empolyed: a slow timescale for association decisions and a fast timescale for power allocation and packet-level transmissions, enabling precise evaluation of network performance. Extensive simulations demonstrate that packet delays are significantly reduced by this approach compared to conventional methods, including user association with the nearest AP or association that maximizes the signal-to-noise-and-interference ratio, particularly in scenarios marked by high traffic, heterogeneous traffic distributions, or uneven user densities. The trained policies also show robust scalability across diverse network sizes and traffic conditions.

title: Analyzing Sources of Fingerprints in Wireless Modules Using Microwave Measurements
authors: Vishnuvardhan V. Iyer, Jacob D. Rezac, James C. Booth
publish: 2025 IEEE Physical Assurance and Inspection of Electronics (PAINE)
abstract: We investigate sources of fingerprints in wireless transceiver circuits using near-field and wave parameter measurements independently. We focus on different configurations of amplifiers and filters, and analyze the measurement modalities' frequency response as a function of input power. Device-dependent features are identified by performing dimensionality reduction on the measured signals with linear discriminant analysis. Visualizing the clusters of reduced data in a three-dimensional space allows us to demonstrate our ability to fingerprint different device configurations, while observing each configuration's sensitivity to the input power.

title: Enhancing Supervised Learning Performance with Dimensionality Reduction Techniques: PCA, LDA, and ICA
authors: Deny Jollyta, Julianti Kasih, Pihandoko Pihandoko, William Ramdhan, Johan Johan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: One of the challenges in enhancing the performance of models generated by supervised learning algorithms is processing high-dimensional data using reduction techniques. It is still necessary to add knowledge regarding the possibilities of reduction techniques. This research aims to improve the performance of supervised learning algorithms by employing appropriate data reduction techniques. The reduction techniques used are Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) and Independent Component Analysis (ICA) which are explored in the K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) algorithms. The study's findings indicate that RF is the method that yields the most accurate model performance with value in 0.7098 by LDA reduction, whereas LDA has a prediction accuracy of 0.845 for all algorithms. The contribution of this research is the addition of information about the quantity of components that might influence model performance. It is intended that the research's findings would better inform users about how to apply supervised learning algorithms and reduction approaches that are suitable for the data.

title: Classification of Cervical Cancer Cytology Images Based on Morphology and Color Features
authors: Ziming Zeng, Yinlong Zhang, Fengrui Xin
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: The early screening of cervical cancer is of great significance to reduce the mortality rate, but the traditional manual reading has the problems of strong subjectivity and low efficiency. In this paper, a dual-resolution collaborative classification method based on morphological and color features is proposed. The nucleus is accurately segmented by an adaptive active contour model, and a multi-level Adaboost-SVM classifier is designed by combining morphological features (area, ellipse fitting) at low magnification and color features (hue, optical density) at high magnification to achieve automatic screening of abnormal cells. The experimental results show that the sensitivity of the proposed method is 88.9% and the specificity is 100% in 54 clinical smears, which significantly improves the recognition accuracy of abnormal cells and provides an effective solution for intelligent screening of cervical cancer.

title: Addressing STEM Specimen Preparation Challenges in Advanced-Node FinFET Devices
authors: Matthew Cheng, Abinash Kumar, Stephen Schwarz, Ed Perko, Henry Williams, Brenda Prenitzer
publish: 2025 IEEE Physical Assurance and Inspection of Electronics (PAINE)
abstract: Over the past 75 years, microelectronic device miniaturization has been enabled by the development of novel materials and increasingly compact and complex device architectures. Rapid and ongoing evolution of advanced test capabilities is needed to support all aspects of hardware development, manufacturing, quality, security assurance and supply chain verification. Multi-modal and multi-scale test methodologies that build on existing trusted methodologies are needed to combat the array of increasingly sophisticated and diverse threats to device integrity. Advances in architecture place significant demands on metrology, particularly at the densely packed, multi-interface regions in advanced-node devices. Techniques such as scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and atom probe tomography (APT) add to the existing suite of metrology techniques for physical assurance by providing sub-angstrom spatial resolution for detailed atomic-scale analysis. The efficacy of these and other techniques are inextricably linked to the preparation of high quality, representative electron transparent specimens in configurations suitable for each specific technique. Specimen preparation of features at this scale and geometric complexity is non-trivial. Physical constraints dictate that even a perfectly prepared specimen will inescapably contain multiple adjacent and overlapping features resulting in signal convolution when imaged in transmission. Margins for error and tolerance for artifact are vanishingly small considering that nanometer scale misplacement of site-specificity will exacerbate the signal convolution problem, in some cases completely obscuring key information. This paper addresses some of the challenges and physical limitations associated with locating, capturing, and isolating a nm scale feature of interest (FOI) within the volume of an ultra-thin electron transparent STEM specimen. We present a robust, ultra site-specific specimen preparation methodology using focused ion beam (FIB) optimized for STEM analysis, enabling high-resolution structural and chemical characterization of complex nanoscale interfaces with precise isolation of features of interest. Although the specific example presented focuses on the challenges of STEM specimen preparation for FinFET devices at the 4 nm technology node, the concepts presented have broad application to any geometrically complex material system.

title: Graph Attention-Based Interpretable Deviation Network for Circulating Water Pump Situational Awareness
authors: Le Zhang, Wei Cheng, Shuo Zhang, Zelin Nie
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: The increasing complexity and interconnectivity of modern process industry systems, particularly in critical infrastructure such as circulating water pump systems in nuclear and chemical plants, pose significant challenges for ensuring operational security and system-level situational awareness. Conventional deep learning models, while effective in temporal pattern recognition, exhibit limited capability in capturing spatial dependencies across heterogeneous sensor networks, thereby restricting their ability to represent dynamic system behavior. To address these limitations, this paper presents a novel method titled graph attention-based deviation network (GADN4SA) for circulating water system situational awareness. The proposed method dynamically constructs task-aware sensor graphs based on signal correlations, integrates both structural and semantic representations, and leverages attention-guided mechanisms to model long-range spatial-temporal dependencies. In addition, a structured deviation scoring module is incorporated to enable interpretable anomaly quantification and attribution. Extensive experiments on both simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of robustness, accuracy, and generalization, highlighting its effectiveness for deployment in safety-critical industrial environments.

title: PViTH-Net: Pyramidal Vision Transformer Homography Estimation Network for Image Stitching
authors: Sima Soltanpour, Chris Joslin
abstract: Homography estimation is crucial for image stitching in autonomous vehicle applications, enabling seamless multi-view transformations. While convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often struggle with capturing global context, limiting their effectiveness. In this paper, we propose a Pyramidal Vision Transformer (PViT) for homography estimation, which integrates a transformer encoder for global feature extraction and convolutional layers for local feature refinement. Our method is evaluated on an image stitching task, demonstrating 75% and 77% error reduction compared to conventional and learning-based homography estimation approaches, respectively. Additionally, our model achieves an efficient performance by reducing computation time, making it suitable for deployment in autonomous vehicle vision systems.

title: Distributed Cross-Domain Service Function Chains Deployment in LEO Satellite Optical Networks
authors: Haicheng Li, Xiaoke Sun, Yixiang Zhang, Pengfei Lv, Kecai Chen, Yanyan Xie, Ruijie Zhu
abstract: We propose a distributed cross-domain service function chains deployment algorithm for satellite optical networks. Simulation results show it can reduce end-to-end delay, and improve deployment success rate.

title: GNSS NLOS Identification using Sky-view Images and Machine Learning to Enhance Localization Performance in GNSS-challenged Environments
authors: Siyi Wang, Tuan Li, Yuhao Xiao, Zhigang Wang, Ning Fu, Haitao Nie
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: In complex urban environments, Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) positioning accuracy suffers from Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) signals and multipath effects. In this study, we propose a method that combines visual information and machine learning to identify and remove NLOS signals to enhance localization performance in GNSS-challenged environments. We generate LOS/NLOS labels using data from an inertial navigation system (INS) and images from a fisheye camera, and then extract three key features, Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), elevation and azimuth to train machine learning models for signal classification. Classification performance of seven different machine learning models was evaluated for comparison. Experimental results show that deep and ensemble learning models, especially Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) algorithm, achieve higher classification accuracy but lower computational efficiency. Also feature importance analysis highlights elevation as the most influential factor. The GNSS Single Point Positioning (SPP) accuracy is improved significantly with the removal of satellites classified as NLOS, and the positioning accuracy improvement with the MLP algorithm is 22.16% and 29.55% in the horizontal and vertical direction, respectively.

title: Performance Benchmarking of OpenPLC Across Multiple Environments for Cloud-Based Industrial Automation
authors: Junhao Deng, Yan Li, Peng Bo, Yu Liu, Dapeng Lan, Zhibo Pang
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: As traditional analog industrial automation transitions toward digitalization, the efficient deployment of control systems becomes increasingly critical. Open programmable logic controllers (OpenPLC) and the Modbus communication protocol, leveraging the widespread adoption of containerization technologies, are gradually migrating to native cloud architectures. This paper investigates the deployment of OpenPLC in local environments, Docker containers, and Kubernetes clusters, evaluating several key performance indicators, including resource consumption, Modbus communication response time, throughput, multi-user handling, stability, and fault recovery. By designing experimental platforms tailored to different environments and conducting validation across multiple platforms, the experimental results indicate that, although local deployment performs better in terms of low latency and resource consumption, deployments on the Kubernetes platform exhibit significant advantages in fault recovery, throughput, and system stability. In contrast, Docker-based deployments demonstrate more balanced performance, but lag behind Kubernetes in scalability and fault tolerance. Based on the experimental findings, this study provides valuable insights for selecting the optimal deployment strategy for industrial automation systems, taking into account OpenPLC, containerization technologies, performance requirements, and the integration of cloud-fog automation for enhanced flexibility and scalability.

title: A Probabilistic Constellation Shaping Method Based on FSO-OFDM Communication Systems
authors: Xi Fang, Lingxiao Liu, Shun Lv, Bo Wang, Xiaohan Wang, Xutong Zhou
abstract: To address the practical limitations of transceiver power in satellite communication systems, this paper proposes a probabilistic constellation shaping (PCS) scheme. By incorporating a non-uniform probability distribution module along with distribution matchers and dematchers at the transmitter and receiver, the average transmission power is effectively reduced. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed PCS-FSO-OFDM communication system achieves stable 16QAM transmission under clear weather conditions while maintaining transmission capacity, with approximately 12.9 % reduction in average transmit power.

title: Optimizing Imaging Performance of Scanning Fiber Endoscopes
authors: Hao Zhong, Lei Li, Zhipeng Wu, Yutong Yan, Yanlong Meng, Le Wang, Yi Li
abstract: Scanning fiber endoscopy (SFE) achieves helical scanning of the fiber by driving it with a piezoelectric actuator at its resonant frequency, while a photodetector collects the reflected signal to enable miniaturized, high-resolution imaging. This technique shows promising potential in medical diagnostics and minimally invasive surgery. In this work, a single-fiber scanning imaging system was designed and implemented, achieving stable real-time imaging. To address system bias and noise in the experimental signals, Fourier transform was applied to analyze the frequency spectrum, and three filtering methods were compared. The results demonstrate that Fourier filtering offers superior performance in signal fidelity and noise suppression. Furthermore, by integrating linear interpolation into the image reconstruction process, the overall image quality improved by more than 20% compared with the original results. These findings validate the effectiveness of combining frequency-domain filtering with interpolation for optimizing single-fiber scanning imaging, laying a foundation for its future applications in medical imaging.

title: A Fault-Aware Hybrid Scheduling Algorithm Based on Cycle-Specified Queuing and Forwarding for Industrial Internet
authors: Yajie Lin, Fangmin Xu, Chenglin Zhao, Xiaokai Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: The growing scale of industrial internet systems and the demand for real-time wide-area communication expose limitations of conventional time-sensitive mechanisms, especially in handling delay variation, static resource allocation, and fault recovery. This paper proposes a fault-aware hybrid scheduling (FAHS) algorithm for cycle-specified queuing and forwarding (CSQF) networks. FAHS organizes port queues into fixed, elastic, and best-effort (FB/EB/BE) resource blocks and integrates global path control with local queue scheduling to cope with both transient and persistent faults. Discrete-event simulations on a 16 node Internet2-based topology show that FAHS keeps AVB packet loss below 4.2 % under transient faults and reduces recovery time from about 12.1 ms to 4.8 ms compared with a Fault-Reroute scheme, while also lowering AVB loss under persistent faults versus Static-CSQF and Adaptive-CSQF. These results indicate that FAHS enhances determinism and fault tolerance for mixedcriticality industrial internet applications.

title: Uncertainty-Aware GNSS/IMU/Vision Multi-Sensor Fusion Positioning Algorithm for Low-Altitude Economy Applications
authors: Jin Wang, Jun Zou, Decai Zou, Jianbo Du, Pengwu Wan, Jing Jiang
abstract: With the rapid advancements in technologies such as autonomous driving, intelligent robotics, unmanned aerial vehicles, and low-altitude economy applications, the demand for high-precision and highly robust positioning systems has become increasingly critical. Multi-sensor fusion positioning has gained widespread adoption due to its superior accuracy and robustness, with factor graph optimization receiving particular attention for its efficient modeling of multi-source constraints. However, traditional approaches often assume fixed noise levels, neglecting the dynamic variations of uncertainty in complex environments. To address this limitation, this paper proposes an uncertainty-aware GNSS/IMU/Vision multi-sensor fusion positioning algorithm. Recognizing the distinct error characteristics of GNSS and IMU, the error state Kalman filter (ESKF) is first employed to develop dynamic uncertainty models for each sensor. Building upon this, an adaptive weighting factor based on the covariance trace is introduced to apply uncertainty weighting to the GNSS/IMU data, thereby mitigating the impact of error interference during high-noise periods. Finally, the weighted multi-source data, along with visual feature observations, are incorporated into the factor graph optimization framework, enabling global state estimation within a sliding window. The proposed method is validated using the GVINS public dataset, and experimental results demonstrate its superior performance in challenging low-altitude economy scenarios, such as weak GNSS signals and significant IMU drift. Compared to traditional factor graph optimization algorithms, the proposed method improves positioning accuracy by 33% and reduces velocity error by 40%.

title: Energy-Optimized Computation Offloading in MEC-Enabled Cell-Free Massive MIMO Systems with MADDPG
authors: Zhanghao Pan, Yanxiang Jiang, Yige Hang, Fu-Chun Zheng
abstract: This paper introduces a two-stage operational framework for computation offloading in the mobile edge computing (MEC)-enabled cell free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF-mMIMO) systems. The computation offloading task is divided into data transmission and task computing sub-tasks to achieve fine-grained optimization of energy efficiency and reduce task complexity. A staged multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient (MADDPG) algorithm is proposed to solve the energy optimization problem. In the transmission stage, user equipments (UEs) act as agents to optimize the allocation of transmission power, while in the computing stage, access point (AP) clusters act as agents to optimize the allocation of computational resources. The simulation results demonstrate that compared with the baseline algorithm, the proposed scheme can achieve a significant improvement in energy consumption during the transmission stage, and near-optimal performance with lower complexity during the computing stage.

title: Hydrological Information Extraction from Historical Maps Using SAM large model and Mathematical Morphology
authors: Shen Yang, Ke Yuanying, Li Tiankun, Huang Feng, Liu Weihui, Zhang Xingyi, Zhong Zhenhua, Zhao Fei
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Historical maps contain valuable geographic information for analyzing historical patterns and providing insights for contemporary development. Unlike modern maps and remote sensing images, historical maps have been preserved for long periods but face challenges such as limited availability and low resolution. Additionally, their map symbols differ significantly from modern ones, making information extraction inefficient. To address these challenges, this study proposes an intelligent method for extracting hydrological information from historical maps, using the topographic map of ditches and channels along the Yellow River in Ningxia Province as case data. The dataset was constructed by combining clustering methods, symbolic syntax, and mathematical morphology. The SAM structure was refined, and its weights optimized via transfer learning. Hydrological information was then extracted from the historical map using the enhanced SAM model. Experimental results show that this method produces clear boundaries, complete contours, and the highest precision and accuracy. A comparison with the region’s current hydrological conditions reveals that most historical rivers and ditches have been diverted, shifted, or vanished, with a significant reduction in lake areas. This paper improves the SAM model, demonstrating its applicability in historical map analysis and offering a novel approach to map information extraction.

title: Deep Learning for Assembly Deviation Estimation: A UNet-based Contact Point Prediction Approach Using Mating Status Image
authors: Jiarui Wang, Junfeng Wang, Yixin Dong, Yang Mao, Zijian Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Skin model shapes have emerged as a critical tool in assembly deviation analysis. However, the traditional analytical methods struggle with complex geometries and nonlinear relationships. Recent advances in deep learning, with its powerful feature extraction and nonlinear modeling capabilities, present promising solutions to these limitations. This paper explores the integration of skin model shapes with deep learning and proposes Mating Status Image (MSI), a novel 2D representation of 3D difference surface, to facilitate the transition of assembly deviation analysis towards a data-driven paradigm. The proposed Res-UNet module can be integrated into current deviation estimation workflow, enabling parallel contact point prediction and thereby significantly improving computational efficiency. Based on the discrete cosine transform and gaussian random field, we constructed a self-built dataset, with the result of centroid-driven algorithm serving as ground truth. Experiments demonstrate that our method achieves 0.8238 accuracy in contact point prediction, alongside a significant enhancement in computational speed. By leveraging MSI and deep learning, this research advances the transition toward intelligent and efficient of assembly deviation analysis.

title: Polarization-Constrained Orientation for Low-Cost MEMS A Cross-Pair Vector Constraint Approach
authors: Minghui Zou, Lilian Zhang, Xiaofeng He, Chen Fan
abstract: Accurate attitude estimation is vital for autonomous navigation of low-cost UAVs, yet MEMS-based inertial navigation systems (INS) suffer from drift and require reliable external references. This paper proposes a Cross-Pair Vector Constraint Approach to enhance the robustness of polarization-based orientation. By exploiting the stability of near-orthogonal vector cross products, the method selects optimal electric-field vector pairs from polarization images and fuses candidate sun vectors using Degree-of-Polarization (DoP) weighting for a statistically optimal estimate. Simulation results show a 39.3% reduction in RMSE (from 0.056°to 0.034°), while field tests demonstrate an 8.7% improvement in heading accuracy compared with the traditional SVD-based method. The proposed approach effectively suppresses noise amplification and can be directly embedded into an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) framework for real-time polarization–inertial fusion, enabling stable orientation in GNSS-denied environments.

title: Coprime Array-Enhanced STAR-RIS for CRB Optimization in ISAC Systems
authors: Shuyue Qu, Ruihuan Wang, Ruidong Wang, Qimei Chen
abstract: Simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (STAR-RIS) are widely adopted in integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems to sense users in non-line-of-sight (NLoS) scenarios. However, the uniform spacing of elements in the uniform linear array (ULA) imposes fundamental limitations on angular resolution. To address the challenge, we propose replacing the ULA with a coprime array in the sensor module of the STAR-RIS to enhance high-accuracy direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation. Furthermore, we derive the Cramér-Rao bound (CRB) of the proposed architecture, and a joint optimization problem is formulated to minimize the CRB. To solve the problem, we introduce Schur complement to transform the non-convex problem into a Fisher information matrix (FIM) optimization problem, and an efficient dual-loop iterative algorithm based on the penalty dual decomposition method is adopted to resolve it. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed coprime array structure can achieve higher theoretical sensing accuracy compared with the traditional ULA structure.

title: Differential Modulation-Based Beamforming for Full-Duplex SIMO Systems
authors: Zhentao Zhang, Fu-Chun Zheng
abstract: Full-duplex (FD) systems offers the potential for high spectral efficiency but suffers from severe self-interference (SI) and pilot overhead when using conventional channel estimation. We propose a differential modulation (DM)–based beamforming scheme for FD single-input multiple-output (SIMO) systems that eliminates pilot symbols by extracting channel information directly from received signals. Beamforming weights are adaptively updated, minimizing signaling complexity and latency. Taking into account the significant pilot overhead of coherent schemes, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves effective SI suppression and exhibits enhanced robustness in rapidly time-varying channel conditions.

title: A CNN-LSTM Based Beam Tracking Scheme for Next-generation Sub-7GHz and mmWave Integrated Wi-Fi Networks
authors: Yangyang Lv, Li Yan, Xuming Fang, Liuming Lu, Chaoming Luo
abstract: In Wi-Fi mmWave networks, blockage and mobility cause frequent beam switching, risking link stability. In 802.11ad, neighboring beam search method is used to select optimal beams, which only tests the limited candidate directions near the current beam, possibly leading to suboptimal communication performance. To improve the link stability, in this paper we propose a sub-7GHz and mmWave integrated Wi-Fi network architecture, where the omnidirectional sub-7GHz band is leveraged to improve the network coverage. To enhance the beam tracking performance, we further propose a CNN-LSTM based beam tracking scheme, where the CNN-LSTM is leveraged to extract features from both sub-7GHz and partial mmWave channel state information (CSI). Simulation results show that our proposed scheme can improve beam tracking accuracy, reduce beam search time and achieve higher system capacity.

title: Seafood Detection Algorithm Based on DCGAN Network and MDRFF Resnet50 with FPN Faster R-CNN Network
authors: Yuting Wang, Qingqing Hong, Zhen Li, Hui Yang, Haonan Tang, Yuliang Gao, Zijun Yang, Lifeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: The exploitation and utilization of marine resources has always been the focus of people's attention. And seafood aquaculture is always the focus of agricultural development and the exploitation of marine resources. With the development of smart agriculture, the detection and monitoring of seafood has become more intelligent. Due to the complexity of underwater terrain, it is particularly difficult for underwater cameras to acquire images of marine life. Therefore, the detection of marine life often faces problems such as difficulty in acquiring datasets and scarcity of data in datasets. To address the above problems, this paper proposed a seafood detection algorithm based on the combination of deep convolutional generative adversarial network and MDRFF Resnet50 with FPN Faster R-CNN network. The algorithm uses Faster R-CNN as the basic framework for marine life detection and uses deep convolutional generative adversarial network (DCGAN) to generate data for small dataset to effectively expand the dataset without the difficulty of underwater image acquisition. For feature extraction network, we use Resnet50 as backbone and combine with feature pyramid network to enhance the feature extraction capability. We also design a new feature fusion module MDRFF. This module performs multiscale feature extraction and splices them into new features by dilated convolution with different dilation rates. Then the concatenation is weighted and adjusted by channel and spatial attention, and finally outputs a more efficient feature map. From the final experimental results, it can be seen that our proposed method has a good improvement in detection accuracy.

title: Energy-Efficient Computation Offloading in Meta Computing: Joint Power and Resource Optimization with Statistical CSI
authors: Yiliang Liu, Junhao Li, Tiantian Zhang, Zhou Su
abstract: This article investigates the energy-efficient computation offloading problem in a meta computing environment, integrating multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technologies and statistical channel state information (CSI). Existing resource allocation approaches always depend on instantaneous CSI, which is impractical for highly dynamic meta computing scenarios due to rapid CSI fluctuations. To address this issue, we propose a novel computation offloading scheme that jointly optimizes transmit power and computation resource allocation for multi-antenna users by leveraging statistical CSI. Specifically, a closed-form expression for the ergodic capacity and a tight bound for the MIMO diversity transmission scheme are derived. These theoretical results decouple the complex joint optimization into two tractable subproblems, where the ergodic capacity expression is utilized for global computation resource assignment via a Kuhn–Munkres (KM) algorithm, while the bound significantly simplifies the transmit power optimization problem. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves substantial energy consumption reductions compared to conventional methods, highlighting the effectiveness of utilizing statistical CSI in meta computing resource allocation.

title: Handover Mechanism based on Link Quality and Longevity for LEO-based Non-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Chien-Lin Yen, Chih-Cheng Tseng, Shao-Yu Lien, Fang-Chag Kuo, Yao-Jen Liang, Yang Cao
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites in the nonterrestrial networks (NTNs) are challenged by high satellite moving speeds and dynamic link conditions, which lead to frequent and suboptimal handovers. A handover mechanism based on a composite quality indicator (CQI) that balances the trade-off between the quality and longevity of a link is proposed. To capture the nonlinear behavior of the links between the LEO satellites and the user terminal (UT), two logistic functions (LFs) are employed to dynamically adjust the weight to generate the CQI and the value of the handover threshold, respectively. By using the Two-Line Element (TLE) data, a genetic algorithm (GA) is developed to find the optimal parameter values to facilitate the two LFs by searching a multidimensional solution space. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed handover mechanism not only enhances link quality and longevity but also reduces the number of handovers compared to the elevation-based and max remaining visibility time (RVT)-based methods.

title: Multi-Antenna Reference Signal Design for OFDM-ISAC Systems Based on ZCZ Sequences
authors: Congxi Liu, Liang Xia, Fei Xu, Xinran Xu, Hang Long
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is a key technology for next-generation communication systems. Accurate sensing relies on estimating the channel’s delay and Doppler shift using reference signals (RSs), enabling the determination of reflector distances and velocities. In this paper, we propose a multi-antenna RS design for orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM)-based ISAC systems with a single receiving antenna. We exploit the two-dimensional (2D) convolutional characteristics of the delay-Doppler domain channel and the quasi-orthogonality of zero correlation zone (ZCZ) sequences to efficiently separate channel responses from multiple antennas with low complexity. The proposed parameter estimation algorithm is compatible with conventional 2D-fast Fourier transform algorithms. Numerical simulations demonstrate that in single-path scenarios, the estimation performance reaches the Cramér-Rao lower bound (CRLB). However, in multipath scenarios, performance diverges from the CRLB at high signal-to-noise ratios due to interference between paths.

title: Dynamic Assessment of Multi-Task Assignment for Unmanned Swarms in Complex Environments
authors: Yilin Zhao, Jianwei Zhao, Nan Jiang, Fang He, Haojie Hu, Weimin Jia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a dynamic assessment method that integrates the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and Fuzzy Comprehensive Evaluation (FCE) with deep learning techniques. First, a foundational assessment index system is established, encompassing five dimensions. Then, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and Transformer architectures are utilized to process real-time time-series data, enabling dynamic adjustments of indicator weights and membership functions. Adversarial machine learning techniques are incorporated to generate jamming samples for training the assessment model, thereby enhancing its robustness in complex electromagnetic environments. Simulation results indicate that the proposed method maintains an assessment accuracy of over 90% even under high-intensity jamming scenarios.

title: Comparative Study of Digital Holographic Microscopy and Diffraction Phase Microscopy for Quantitative Phase Imaging
authors: Rongmiao Xue, Liwei Guo, Jiao Su, Chen Liu
abstract: Developed a co-localized QPI system integrating DHM and DPM to directly compare noise and imaging performance. Side-by-side evaluation revealed distinct phase artifacts and contrast mechanisms, providing guidelines for technique selection.

title: SDR-YOLOv8: An Improved Remote Sensing Image Object Detection Algorithm Based on YOLOv8
authors: Hao Liu, Xiaodong He, Yishuo Shan
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Computer Technology, Digital Media and Communication
abstract: None

title: Packet Loss Aware Delivery Node Selection for MDS Based LEO Satellite Caching
authors: Xinyu Cui, Yiqing Zhou, Ling Liu, Jinglin Shi, Menghua Cao, Ningzhe Shi
abstract: The maximum distance separable (MDS) coding based caching is effective to reduce the delivery delay of content in low earth orbit (LEO) satellite networks. However, due to the severe packet loss of satellite links and the variations among them, the existing distance aware delivery node selection methods may lead to significant packet loss and delivery delay. To solve this problem, a packet loss aware delivery node selection method is proposed in this paper. First, the delivery delay of coded sub-contents is analyzed by taking packet loss into account. And the delivery node selection problem is formulated as a delivery delay minimization problem. Then, the problem is divided into multiple sub-problems according to the time slot, where each sub-problem is a single-constraint knapsack problem. Based on the Edmonds theorem, the greedy algorithm is used to obtain the optimal solution. Finally, simulations are carried out on a walkerdelta constellation to verify the performance of the proposed method. And the results show that the user perceived packet loss and the packet retransmission induced delivery delay can be reduced by 83% and 42.8%, respectively, when compared with the existing distance aware delivery node selection method.

title: A Random Access Protocol for Ambient IoT Based on Collision Constellation Diagram
authors: Qian Qiao, Shaoyi Xu
abstract: Ambient backscatter devices have been demonstrated to have significant potential in a variety of IoT applications. These devices are notable for their low-cost and low power consumption, which facilitates their massive deployment in numerous scenarios. However, due to the extensive deployment as well as the constraints of low power and cost, traditional random access protocols are not well-suited to such backscatter communication scenarios. In this article, a demodulation strategy for two packets colliding is presented, which was realised by analysing the collision constellation diagram and the meanings of collision clusters with a training sequence. Subsequently, this strategy is used to design a random access protocol for this large-scale access scenario. In addition, we also analyse the performance of the proposed protocol using a bipartite graph and design an optimization problem to gain the suboptimal probability distribution of the number of packet copies to further improve the access performance. The final simulation results imply that the performance of the proposed protocol is significantly enhanced in comparison to traditional protocols.

title: LLM En-powered UAV Networks Control for Efficient Wireless Communication
authors: Yue Zhang, Haibo Mei, Junyu Lai, Shuang Du
abstract: Currently, Large Language Model (LLM), as a typical Generative AI (GAI) implementation, has been deployed to lead to artificial general intelligence for numerous applications. Numbers of LLM releases, like ChatGPT, Llama, Gemini, ChatGLM, can online interact with users to give instructions against different kinds of queries. Moreover, LLMs can process multi-model data, like text, image, voice, video, to support the workings of robots, expert systems, and operation control systems. Due to its merits, LLM in theory can help the operation of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) communication networks, where each UAV is constrained by its size, weight and power (SWAP) to provide limited data collection functions in the air. In this paper, we apply LLM to online control the operation of UAVs by optimizing the trajectory of UAV , to lead to UAV energy efficiency. We firstly provide well established air-ground wireless communication model within UAV and ground terminals (GTs) to provide API library to LLM to help its closed-loop reasoning. Further, we establish Chain-of-Thought (CoT) and generate optimizing instructions to support UAV communication via prompt engineering. In the end, such LLM en-powered UAV communication network will be validated via experiments. The numerical results validate that LLM can enable UAV communication networks to more adaptive to complicated environments to work with less energy consumption and higher energy efficiency.

title: The Effect of Stemming Method on The Performance of SVM for Sentiment Analysis
authors: Aisyah Larasati, Rudi Nurdiansyah, Vertic E.B. Darmawan, Nikmatus Sholikha, Yuh-Wen Chen, Agus Rachmad Purnama
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: This study aims to analyze the effect of stemming methods, which are Nazief-Adriani and Porter, on the performance of the SVM Model for sentiment analysis. This study retrieves data by scraping customer reviews on Google Play and takes 10,000 data samples to do the experiment. There are 144 experimental combinations. This study uses the classical method as its stop-word removal method. The performance of the classifier model is measured based on the accuracy, computation time, and Receiver Operating Characteristics (ROC) curve. The SVM model parameters to be set are C, gamma, and kernel type. This study performs a grid search optimization to find the best parameter of the SVM model. This study finds that SVM with RBF kernel function, Porter stemming, and classical removal method results in the best accuracy and the highest area under the ROC curve. This study also finds that a 50%:50% data distribution of the class label (a balanced data set) does not always result in a better performance compared to a 70%:30 data distribution (an imbalanced data set).

title: A Novel Base Station Deployment Scheme for Network Planning in 6G Outdoor Hotspot Scenarios
authors: Dantong Chen, Shuaifei Chen, Songjiang Yang, Jie Huang, Xiping Wu, Cheng-Xiang Wang
abstract: The explosive growth of the sixth-generation ( 6 G ) wireless system necessitates efficient base station (BS) deployment to balance coverage, data rates, and economic costs. In this paper, we propose a novel BS deployment scheme that jointly optimizes the number and locations of the deployed BSs, considering limited BS throughputs and practical non-uniform user distributions. A variant multi-dimensional knapsack problem is formulated and then solved by proposing a novel depth-limited backtracking dynamic programming (DLB-DP) algorithm with a BS-user association (BSUA) algorithm. We compare the proposed DLB-DP algorithm with three state-of-the-art benchmark algorithms in a hotspot scenario. The results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms the considered alternatives in terms of coverage, data rates, and robustness under varying user densities.

title: Priority-Aware Hybrid MAC Protocol for Vehicular Networks
authors: Xinru Zhao, Tao Huang, Yao Wei, Pengxiang Li, Jungang Ge
abstract: Multiple Access Control (MAC) mechanism is imperative for Vehicular Ad-hoc Network (VANET) communications, which directly impacts system performance. IEEE 1609.4 protocol is dedicated to address the issue of MAC in VANETs. The protocol divides channels into a Control Channel (CCH) and Service Channels (SCHs), where nodes compete in CCH to gain access to SCHs to transmit data. However, this mechanism fails to guarantee Quality of Service (QoS) performance of heterogeneous services. To cope with this situation, this paper proposes a novel Priority-Aware Hybrid MAC protocol (PAH-MAC) for VANETs, enhancing QoS by introducing differentiated transmission schemes for Vehicular to Vehicular (V2V) and Vehicular to Infrastructure (V2I) communications. For V2V links, emergency data is broadcast directly in CCH to earn the highest channel access priority. For V2I links, service data is further classified into two priority levels. Safety-critical service packets employ a preemption-based TDMA scheme to ensure the opportunity of transmission in SCHs higher than regular service packets. And V2I regular service packets follow a TDMA-based reservation mechanism but will defer transmission if preempted by emergency service packets. This design optimizes spectrum efficiency while guaranteeing QoS for critical V2I services. Furthermore, we develop an analytical framework based on an M/D/1 tandem M/M/4 queueing model and a deferred reservation model, followed by theoretical and simulation-based evaluations. The simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed scheme in terms of throughput and control overhead compared with typical IEEE 1609.4 under high mobility of VANET.

title: Kriging-based Sobol Sensitivity Analysis for Design of Experiments under Correlated Inputs
authors: Shixuan Zhang, Jie Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: During the industrial production and development test process, multiple high-cost field tests are required to optimize or verify the quality of the product. Sensitivity analysis can determine the factors that have an important impact on the product in the early stage of the test and screen out the important factors for sequential testing. When the test sample is small, sensitivity analysis of a small number of samples is often difficult, especially when the inputs are correlated. A Kriging-based Sobol sensitivity analysis strategy for correlated inputs is proposed under the above questions. Comparisons with BP neural network and SVM are performed under mathematical simulation and precise experiments to demonstrate.

title: Bone Age Prediction using a Convolutional Neural Network-based Regression Algorithm employing Attention-Directing and Cluster
authors: Tao Ma, Tinghong Ye, Lixin Deng, Yizhu Tang, TakMan LO, Kaip Tse, Jiatao Wu, Yuzhi Huang, Zhihao Li, Renzhi Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Bone age assessment (BAA) is a critical research topic in pediatric radiology, with growing interest in developing automated BAA methods. This study proposes a bone age prediction model integrating cluster analysis and convolutional neural network (CNN) regression, further enhanced by a multi-scale attention mechanism to construct a "divide-and-focus" dual-driven deep learning framework. Targeting age-sensitive regional features in hand radiographs, we innovatively design an adaptive spatial attention module that achieves hierarchical anatomical feature enhancement through saliency detection of attention-guided regions of interest (ROI). The algorithm first uses multiconstrained clustering of K methods to generate age-specific subsets, followed by parallel execution on each subset: 1) attention-guided ROI segmentation and feature enhancement; 2) validation of the base CNN regression networks (including ResNet, DenseNet and EfficientNetV2); 3) set of cross-subset models with Bayesian-optimized weighting strategies for final prediction. By synergistically integrating the data distribution priors with attention-driven anatomical priors, the method delivers interpretable solutions when performing medical image regression tasks. The modular design ensures compatibility with mainstream CNN architectures. The method will aid pediatric growth monitoring and the diagnosis of endocrine disorders.

title: 200 GBaud Transmitter Based on a 1064 nm Lithium Niobate Mach Zehnder Modulator
authors: Darja Cirjulina, Toms Salgals, Armands Ostrovskis, Hadrien Louchet, Michael Koenigsmann, Fabio Pittalà, Benjamin Krüger, Lu Zhang, Xianbin Yu, Richard Schatz, Stefan Dahlfort, Nicolas Grossard, Robert Jahn, Kazuo Yamaguchi, Markus Gruen, Vjaceslavs Bobrovs, Xiaodan Pang, Oskars Ozolins
abstract: We demonstrate 200 GBaud OOK, transmitter using a 1064 nm lithium niobate Mach-Zehnder modulator (MZM). We achieve performance below 6.25 % overhead HDFEC threshold and study different equalization configurations.

title: RadioPix2pix: A GAN-based Style Transfer Model for 2D Radio Map Estimation
authors: Zhiyuan Liu, Shuai Shao
abstract: Radio Map Estimation (RME) plays a crucial role in wireless network planning and optimization, enabling efficient resource allocation and interference management. Unlike traditional methods that rely on transmitter locations, sampling point-based approaches offer greater practical benefits by leveraging real-world measurements. In this paper, we argue that RME should be treated not merely as a generative task but rather as a style transfer problem, where the goal is to transform sparse sampling point distributions into high-fidelity radio maps. To this end, we propose RadioPix2pix, a Generative Adversarial Network GAN-based model with physical awareness that effectively learns the mapping between sparse measurements and dense radio maps. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms deep learning baselines, achieving superior performance even at an extremely low sampling rate of 0.15%. This work provides a novel perspective on RME and advances the state-of-the-art in data-driven radio map reconstruction.

title: Attention-Based Auto-encoder for Graph Anomaly Detection
authors: Shaobo Yang, Cheng Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Graph Anomaly Detection (GAD) is a technique used to detect anomalous graph nodes, which is very important in industrial informatics, particularly in cybersecurity, industrial IoT (IIoT), and intelligent monitoring systems. It is widely used for detecting network intrusions, sensor anomalies, and fraudulent behaviors in smart manufacturing, power grids, and industrial automation. In recent years, graph anomaly detection has been mainly based on graph autoencoder (GAE) and comparative learning. Among them, GAE utilizes the reconstruction loss of the graph to estimate the anomalous nodes. However, the existing methods ignore the negative offset problem of abnormal nodes in obtaining node representations. In the graph, there are far more normal nodes than abnormal nodes, and the features of abnormal nodes are diluted by the features of normal nodes during message passing, which affects the model’s ability to detect abnormal nodes. Therefore, we propose AAE-GAD, a graph anomaly detection method based on the attention mechanism of online updates, to solve this problem. Specifically, first, we obtain the local anomaly scores of all nodes by training a local model, extract a set of normal nodes with high confidence, and compute the hybrid attention weights based on the similarity of the nodes’ central representations with the set of normal nodes and the difference of the anomaly scores with their neighboring nodes. Secondly, we get the node representation by modifying the mechanism of message passing and utilizing the hybrid attention weights in the global model to perform dynamic message passing, and the reconstructed graph can better identify the anomalous nodes. Finally, we continuously update the hybrid attention score using the anomaly score obtained from the global model to make it more discriminative. Extensive experiments on six datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AAE-GAD, and AAE-GAD achieves good results in anomaly detection for contextual and structural types. In highlight, AAE-GAD achieves significant results on the Enron dataset.

title: An Air-Ground Cooperative Pseudo-Satellite Deployment Method Based on the Improved NSGA-III Algorithm
authors: Min Deng, Hongjun Ji, Yongfa Zhao, Zhiqiang Yao
abstract: Global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) are susceptible to interference signals. When the critical navigation zone encounters severe large-scale GNSS interference, the rapid construction of a regional navigation augmentation system based on pseudo-satellite technology is of great strategic and application value for national security through forming a sustained navigation capability. However, the existing pseudo-satellite deployment algorithms are only suitable for ideal scenarios, without considering the air-ground cooperative deployment. To solve these problems, this paper constructs a multi-objective optimization model for pseudo-satellite deployment that takes the signal coverage, positioning accuracy, deployment cost and time into account. These evaluation indexes are analyzed with the presence of signal occlusion and propagation loss by adopting the DEM (Digital Elevation Model). Then, an improved Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III (NSGA III) is proposed to solve it. The genetic operation is designed with a five-element individual integer coding and normalization mapping. Besides, an adaptive change crossover/mutation distribution index is used in algorithm iteration to accelerate the convergence speed. The simulation results show that the proposed algorithm can optimize the deployment strategy by reducing deployment time and cost, and improving flight endurance while ensuring coverage and positioning accuracy in different deployment areas.

title: Weakly Labeled Ovarian Cancer Pathological Image Classification Based on Self-Supervised and Multi-Relational Graph Learning
authors: Shiqiang Zhang, Zongmei Zhang, Bin Wang, Jiashuo Shi, Huaiping Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Ovarian cancer is one of the most common and highly lethal gynecological malignancies, and its early diagnosis and accurate subtyping are of great clinical significance. Whole-slide images (WSI) contain rich tissue structural information required for pathological diagnosis and are often regarded as the "gold standard". However, due to their high resolution and high annotation cost, they typically only have patient-level weak labels. To address the insufficient feature representation under weak labeling and fully explore the potential histological correlations among instances, this paper proposes an ovarian cancer pathological image classification method based on Self-Supervised and multi-relational graph learning (SS-MRGL). First, self-supervised learning is employed to pre-train weakly labeled image instances, obtaining robust and discriminative compressed feature representations. Then, a multi-relational graph is constructed, and a multi-perspective joint modeling approach using Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) and Graph Attention Networks (GAT) is introduced to capture the spatial topological and contextual semantic multi-dimensional information among instances, respectively. Finally, a gated attention mechanism is used to dynamically fuse graph-level features. Experimental results on the YN-OCPD dataset demonstrate that the proposed method can significantly improve the accuracy of ovarian cancer diagnosis under weak supervision.

title: Joint Time-Frequency Offset Estimation Method in Distributed Antenna System
authors: Yuliang Song, Lin Mei, Bo Zhang, Zhiyang Li, Zhaopeng Du, Suiyao Zhu, Bin Wang
abstract: Existing distributed antenna system (DAS) synchronization methods typically only focus on scenarios involving multiple time or frequency offsets and use independent detection methods, which results in poor real-time performance. In this paper, we propose a lightweight detection method based on CAZAC sequences (LDCS) for joint time-frequency offset estimation in DAS. Meanwhile, due to the influence of fading channel, we develop a two-step synchronization strategy-based peak detection algorithm to identify effective antennas. Based on the detection results, we can estimate the time offsets and integer frequency offsets (IFOs) between different effective transmit-receive antenna pairs. Furthermore, we utilize cyclic correlation operations to complete the estimation of fractional frequency offsets (FFOs). This is a multi-parameter estimation method based on time-domain signal processing, which has higher real-time performance and lower computational complexity. The simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed scheme in estimating time-frequency offsets for synchronization.

title: Data Utilization, Methodological Frameworks, and Evaluation Metrics in Head Circumference Measurement Research: A Systematic Review
authors: Dhani Syahputra Bukit, Pauzi Ibrahim Nainggolan, Fahrurrozi Lubis, Ivanny Putri Marianto, Wilbert Neilson Sachio, Riza Sulaiman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: Head circumference measurement is a critical indicator for evaluating infant nutritional status and developmental progress. This review analyzes fourteen studies that utilize diverse imaging modalities—including ultrasound, computed tomography, smartphone photogrammetry, structured light scanning, and RGB-D sensors—to obtain 2D images (with resolutions ranging from 416×416 to 800×540 pixels) and 3D data such as scans, models, sequences, or meshes. Measurement methodologies vary, with seven studies employing deep learning techniques (e.g., ResNet-101, geometric CNNs, U-Net, V-Net variants), six using traditional computer vision methods (e.g., Scale-Invariant Feature Transform, Gauss-Newton optimization, thresholding), and one integrating deep learning (YOLOv5) with machine learning (random forest). Validation metrics demonstrate strong performance, including Dice similarity coefficients between 93.6% and 97.9%, Pearson correlations up to 0.98 (r<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> up to 0.954), classification accuracies from 60% to 99.0%, Hausdorff distances between 1.29 ± 0.79 mm and 2.16 mm, and mean absolute errors below 0.74 cm to 2.27 mm. Deep learning approaches generally achieve measurement precision comparable or superior to traditional techniques when robust segmentation and artifact minimization are ensured. Challenges remain regarding imaging noise, heterogeneity in acquisition protocols, limited annotated datasets, and hardware calibration. Promising directions include real-time implementation, seamless integration into clinical workflows, and applications in telehealth and home monitoring environments.

title: Systematic Literature Review on Implementation Barriers and Adjustment Strategies for Development Methodologies in Startups
authors: Bobby A. Rodriguez, Fidel Rojo, Eddie G. De Paula, Russel M. De La Torre
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: This study presents a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) aimed at identifying implementation barriers and adjustment strategies for software development methodologies in startups. Guided by two research questions— (RQ1) What barriers do startups face? and (RQ2) What strategies help overcome these barriers? —The review analyzed 125 empirical, peer-reviewed studies published from 2020 to 2025, sourced from IEEE Xplore, ACM Digital Library, and ScienceDirect. Study selection followed PRISMA 2020 guidelines and applied a modified PICO framework and quality assessment checklist, with 85% of studies meeting the quality threshold. Inter-rater reliability using Kendall’s Coefficient of Concordance confirmed strong agreement among reviewers. Thematic synthesis revealed cultural barriers (n=74) as most prevalent, followed by organizational (n=24) and technical issues (n=18). Key strategies included agile/hybrid adaptation (n=32), leadership and cultural alignment (n=24), and training (n=15). Startups also employed sector-specific customizations, stakeholder engagement, and iterative improvements. Hybrid startups combined Agile, Lean, and other methodologies to address complex needs. Sector-focused startups, like those in healthcare or public services, require tailored responses to legal and structural challenges. The review highlights the importance of flexible, context-aware strategies to support successful implementation in dynamic startup environments and offers practical insights for researchers and practitioners seeking to enhance development outcomes.

title: Simultaneous Humidity and Temperature Sensing Based on Fiber Optic Microsphere Probes
authors: Wenwen Qian, Peiran He, Zhewen Ding, Li Zhang, Zhixiang Huang, Chunliu Zhao
abstract: Simultaneous humidity-temperature sensing based on dual fiber microsphere probes is proposed. By FFT/filtering for spectral separation, the sensitivities are achieved with 1.22 nm/%RH and 0.54 nm/°C.

title: Analysis of 24/7 Remote Arctic Monitoring by Low Earth Orbit Satellites
authors: Kiarash Yousefi Damavandi, Scott S.-H. Yam, Francois Chan, Ning Lu, Jianbing Ni
abstract: This paper investigates the feasibility and optimization of 24/7 remote monitoring in the Arctic using Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite constellations, specifically Starlink. Through rigorous link analysis incorporating Equivalent Isotropic Radiated Power (EIRP), Gain-to-Noise Temperature ratio (G/T), free space path loss, and rain attenuation, we assess the Carrier-to-Noise Ratio (CNR) for a specified Arctic location. To enhance system reliability, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is applied to optimize satellite constellation parameters, substantially improving visibility from an initial 92.2% to 96.67%. Further optimization via the Walker-Star constellation achieves an unprecedented 100% visibility for a three-month duration. Results highlight the critical impact of atmospheric conditions, satellite configuration, and elevation angles on the overall communication performance, demonstrating a robust methodology for ensuring continuous, reliable Arctic communication. MATLAB (R2024a), MATLAB Satellite Communications Toolbox ver. 24.1, and Aerospace Toolbox ver. 24.1 were used for the analysis in this paper. Some analysis in this paper was done using the computing resources provided by BC DRI Group and Digital Research Alliance of Canada. The satellite data was retrieved from space-track.org.

title: TCP-AAD: An Aggregation-Aware ACK Delaying Mechanism for TCP over Wi-Fi
authors: Shinnazar Seytnazarov, Daler Zakirov
abstract: In the transmission control protocol (TCP), the receiver is required to send acknowledgment (ACK) segments to inform the sender about the successful reception of the data segments. In wireless networks such as Wi-Fi, TCP ACKs introduce additional contention in the shared wireless channel that adversely affects the end-to-end TCP performance. But thanks to the cumulative nature of TCP ACKs, the receiver can send fewer ACKs. A number of studies have improved TCP’s performance on Wi-Fi by using various ACK reduction schemes. However, none have taken advantage of the important property of Wi-Fi’s frame aggregation scheme, which carries multiple data segments and thus causes bulk arrivals at the receiver. This property can be efficiently exploited to dramatically reduce the number of TCP ACKs. We propose an aggregation-aware ACK delaying (TCP-AAD) scheme where the receiver TCP sends only one ACK segment for all data segments received in a single Wi-Fi aggregate frame. This approach significantly reduces the number of ACKs, leading to less contention on the shared wireless medium and increased end-to-end throughput. The proposed and existing schemes were implemented in the ns-3 simulator, and their performance was evaluated for various numbers of stations, as well as different distances between stations and the access point.

title: Multi-Resolution Codebook-Based Beam Training for RIS Beamforming: Design and Experiments
authors: Jiahao Gao, Shuhao Zeng, Boya Di, Lingyang Song
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) has emerged as a promising solution to enable ultra-massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) for 6G wireless communications. To reduce pilot overhead, multi-resolution codebook-based beam training has been proposed for RIS-aided communication systems. However, the hardware constraints of the RIS such as the limited control capability, mutual coupling, and manufacturing tolerances have not been fully considered, which may result in non-ideal beam patterns and misleading beam search directions, thereby degrading the overall beam training performance. To address this issue, in this paper, we revisit the multi-resolution codebook design and beam training scheme by taking the RIS hardware constraints into account. First, we propose a wide-beam generation method via multi-beam superposition, where the RIS reflection coefficients are optimized to achieve high beam gain with minimal fluctuations. Then, a posterior-based beam training scheme is proposed to adaptively correct erroneous beam search directions, thereby improving the beam training accuracy. We implement a prototype RIS with 32x32 reflective elements and deploy a 26 GHz millimeter-wave RIS-aided wireless communication testbed to experimentally evaluate the proposed scheme. The results indicate that our approach achieves low training overhead and a data rate close to the exhaustive search method.

title: A Multi-Channel Interference Separation Method Utilizing the Compound Conjugate Skew-Symmetric Property of Target Echo
authors: Xiangyu Zhu, Endi Zhu, Qi Wang, Yang Zhang, Jiadong Wang, Yachao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: Due to the challenges associated with separating source signals that exhibit similar statistical distributions, as well as the ambiguity regarding the ordering of separated signals following separation in conventional blind source separation (BSS) anti-jamming techniques, this study introduces an innovative separation methodology. The approach leverages the inherent differences between the target echo signal and the interference signal as the foundation for separation. By constructing an optimization function, the method allows for the accurate estimation of the demixing vector, thereby facilitating the effective extraction of the target echo signal. This technique overcomes the constraints of traditional separation methods, which typically depend on the statistical independence of signals, while also ensuring the successful separation of the desired target signal. The Simulation experiment results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Secrecy Improvement Using Active Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces and Leveraging Guard Zones
authors: Sumit Chakravarty, Ying Xie
abstract: This paper investigates the optimization of secure communication in reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted wireless networks by leveraging guard zones and maximizing coverage probability. The guard zone, dynamically centered around the edge user, provides spatial isolation from eavesdroppers, enhancing the probability of secrecy (PoS). However, the guard zone size inversely affects the probability of coverage (PoC) creating a trade-off between coverage and security. To address this, we propose a joint optimization framework for RIS configuration and guard zone size to meet a desired secrecy threshold while maximizing PoC. Using Monte Carlo simulations, we evaluate the interplay between guard zone size, RIS phase shift design, and the spatial distribution of users and eavesdroppers. The results indicate that the proposed approach ensures strong secrecy performance and efficient coverage, providing a flexible and effective solution for secure communication in next-generation wireless networks.

title: AI-Enhanced CSI Feedback via Exploiting Multi-user Shared Information in mMIMO Systems
authors: Yekang Wang, Shanzhi Chen, Shaoli Kang, Xianjun Yang, Mingyu Jia, Yuqi Xue
abstract: In massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) frequency division duplex (FDD) systems, user equipment (UEs) must feed back the channel state information (CSI) to the base station (BS) over the uplink to enhance spectral efficiency. However, in the millimeter wave (mmWave) or higher frequency bands, the significant increase in the number of transmit antennas results in prohibitive feedback overhead. To tackle this issue, we propose a deep learning based multi-user CSI compression framework called CoTransNet. For users in a neighboring area, CSI can be decomposed into two components: one is shared by all users in the area and another is unique to each individual UE. By leveraging shared information, CoTransNet extracts correlations among channels and eliminates redundant feedback information. Experimental results indicate that employing the CoTransNet architecture leads to an average improvement of approximately 4.98% in squared generalized cosine similarity (SGCS) across diverse feedback budgets and a reduction of about 3.54 dB in normalized mean-squared error (NMSE).

title: Diffusion model-based Channel Estimation for Holographic MIMO Systems
authors: Zicheng Lin, Hongliang Zhang
