title: Lithium-ion Battery Health Estimation Using Electric Vehicle Field Data
authors: Luteng Zhong, Zicheng Fei
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Accurately estimating the state of health (SOH) of electric vehicle (EV) batteries is crucial for effective battery management and optimization. This paper proposes a novel datadriven SOH estimation framework for in-vehicle lithium-ion batteries, which is validated based on real-world EV driving data. In the proposed method, preprocessing is first applied to the raw field data, including outlier removal, extraction of charging/discharging segments, and SOH labeling. Subsequently, a set of key battery health features are extracted from the processed sensor data, including various statistics of battery pack voltage, current, temperature, as well as vehicle operational data such as mileage, speed, etc. These extracted features provide a comprehensive representation of in-vehicle battery degradation behavior. Next, a hybrid deep neural network model, integrating the convolutional neural network, temporal convolution network, and attention mechanism, is developed to map these features to battery SOH. Numerical experiments are conducted using data from 13 real-world EVs. The results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves accurate SOH estimation, effectively capturing the degradation dynamics of EV batteries in real-world conditions.

title: Sleep Health Classification Based on Digital Device Usage and Lifestyle Behavior Using Machine Learning
authors: Insidini Fawwaz, Anandhini Medianty Nababan, Rina Anugrahwaty, Lois Pranata Sembiring, Muhammad Dzaky Aulia Akbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: Sleep health is an important component of overall health, but it is increasingly affected by excessive use of digital devices and lifestyle behaviors. This study proposes a machine learning framework to classify sleep health into three categories: Good, Moderate, and Poor using behavioral and digital features. The dataset was processed through cleaning, encoding, normalization, and class balancing with SMOTE. Five classifiers (LightGBM, XGBoost, CatBoost, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting) were implemented and evaluated through cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning. The experimental results showed that Gradient Boosting achieved the highest performance, with an accuracy of 94.82% and balanced precision, recall, and F1 scores across all classes. Further SHAP analysis identified key features such as phone usage hours, total screen time, and physical activity. These findings highlight the potential of explainable ensemble methods, particularly Gradient Boosting, to support practical applications in sleep health monitoring and early lifestyle interventions.

title: A Review of Multi-Criteria Decision Making in Collaborative Network Organizations with AIoT Integration
authors: Mesran, Poltak Sihombing, Syahril Efendi, Muhammad Zarlis
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: This study presents a systematic literature review combined with bibliometric analysis of Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM) models within Collaborative Network Organizations (CNOs), emphasizing the emerging role of Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things (AIoT) integration in decision-making processes. Using the Scopus database, 108 relevant publications from 1988 to 2023 were analyzed to identify publication trends, leading countries, influential works, and collaborative networks. The results indicate a growing interest in AIoT-enabled MCDM approaches across domains such as business, public administration, and disaster response. The United States emerges as the most prolific contributor, while key research themes include collaborative networks, multi-agent systems, and supply chain management. This study highlights existing research gaps and provides insights for future investigations aiming to advance adaptive, sustainable decision-making in CNOs leveraging AIoT technologies.

title: A Self-Tuning Kalman Filter Estimator for Online System Identification of H-bridge Inverter Systems
authors: Yuan Huang, Matthew Armstrong, Shafiq Odhano, Zhenlin Wang, Zepeng Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: This paper introduces a parameter estimation technique for power electronic inverter-based systems. Specific attention is given to the real-time parameter estimation of dc-ac switched-mode power converters; Nevertheless, the proposed method can be applied to many alternative applications where efficient and accurate parameter estimation is required. The proposed scheme is computationally efficient, based on a Kalman filter algorithm, and uses an infinite impulse response adaptive filter as the plant model. The system identification scheme reduces the complexity of computation of existing typical adaptive algorithms. Importantly, the proposed approach can also identify the parameters fast and accurately, thus providing an efficient hardware solution that is suitable for real-time applications. In doing so, the uncertainties of VSIs can be identified by estimated parameters changes. The analysis of simulation and verification based on experimental data from a prototype flexible dc-ac converter is presented. Results clearly demonstrate that the estimated parameters of the dc-ac converter are a high match to the real experimental system. The scheme can be directly employed on adaptive and self-tuning digital controllers to improve control performance of a wide range of renewable energy applications.

title: Sensing Mutual Information for Target-Mounted IRS-Enabled Wireless Sensing
authors: Peilan Wang, Yuting Lin, Lei Xie, Weidong Mei, Jun Fang
abstract: Target-mounted intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) introduce a novel degree of freedom (DoF) in controlling the target’s radar cross section (RCS), thereby enabling numerous advanced applications in wireless sensing and integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems. Nevertheless, a comprehensive analytical framework characterizing the impact of IRS reflection coefficients on wireless sensing performance remains largely unexplored in existing literature. To address this gap, this paper investigates sensing mutual information (SMI) in a general scenario where a sensing transmitter (TX) sends random signals to multiple targets each equipped with an IRS, and multiple sensing receivers (RXs) process the received echoes. We derive a closed-form tight upper bound on SMI and propose an efficient manifold optimization-based method to maximize it by jointly optimizing the transmit precoder and IRS reflection coefficients. Simulation results validate our analysis and demonstrate substantial enhancements in SMI achieved by the proposed method.

title: A Residual Convolutional Fusion Network for AUV Mixed Faults Diagnosis Based on Multi-Sensor Information Fusion
authors: Qingxu Meng, Chenxing Ni, Chen Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: The underwater propulsion system is a vital component of marine equipment such as ships, submarines, and unmanned underwater vehicles, making accurate fault diagnosis essential for ensuring operational reliability. However, existing data-driven methods face key challenges: the absence of a comprehensive mixed fault dataset, difficulty in extracting features from nonlinear and dynamically coupled signals, and sensor data imbalance caused by varying sensor reliability. To address these issues, we propose a Residual Convolutional Fusion Network (RCFN) that incorporates three core modules—double-loop residual convolution, feature reconstruction, and multi-sensor interactive fusion. RCFN enhances feature extraction, reduces redundancy, and improves the integration of multi-sensor data. Experimental results demonstrate that RCFN achieves a 3.2%–10.5% improvement in fault recognition accuracy over baseline models. Furthermore, we developed a dedicated experimental platform and constructed a comprehensive mixed fault dataset using four types of sensors to simulate four single faults and seven mixed faults in underwater propulsion systems.

title: Physical Layer Security for NOMA-OFDM using Power Hopping
authors: T. Assaf, A. Al-Dweik, Y. Iraqi
abstract: This paper presents a novel physical layer security (PLS) scheme for non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) systems that jointly enhances secrecy and bit error rate (BER). The proposed approach leverages power hopping (PH), wherein users’ power coefficients are dynamically allocated to obscure both the decoding order and actual power allocation from potential eavesdroppers. This uncertainty significantly reduces the feasibility of successful interception. Analytical expressions for the BER and secrecy outage probability (SOP) are derived under diverse channel conditions and eavesdropping scenarios. The theoretical findings, validated through Monte Carlo simulations, confirm that the proposed scheme robustly preserves the secrecy of legitimate users regardless of the eavesdropper’s channel quality. Moreover, the approach yields substantial improvements in both BER and SOP, particularly for the near user.

title: Transfer Learning Guided Noise Reduction for Automatic Modulation Classification
authors: Zelin Ji, Shuo Wang, Kuojun Yang, Peng Ye
abstract: Automatic modulation classification (AMC) has emerged as a key technique in smart radio environments in sixth-generation (6G) communications. AMC enables effective data transmission and supports deep connectivity without requiring prior knowledge of modulation schemes. However, the low classification accuracy under the condition of low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) limits the implementation of AMC techniques under the rapidly changing physical channels in 6G and beyond. This paper investigates the AMC technique for the signals with dynamic and varying SNRs, and a deep learning based noise reduction network is proposed to reduce the noise introduced by the wireless channel and the receiving equipment. In particular, a transfer learning guided learning framework (TNR-AMC) is proposed to utilize the scarce annotated modulation signals and improve the classification accuracy for low SNR modulation signals. The numerical results show that the proposed noise reduction network achieves an accuracy improvement of over 20% in low SNR scenarios, and the TNR-AMC framework can improve the classification accuracy under unstable SNRs.

title: Gate-Integrated GaN Diodes for High-Speed Optical Communication
authors: Muhammad Hunain Memon, Yang Kang, Alireza Hosseini, Zhixiang Gao, Haiding Sun
abstract: Gate-integrated GaN dual-functional light-emitting and detecting diodes achieve high-speed optical communication across visible and solar-blind spectra through electrostatic carrier control, enabling compact, energy-adaptive, and bias-circuit-free optoelectronic integration for next-generation photonic systems.

title: Near-field NOMA-SWIPT Assisted with Dynamic Metasurface Antennas
authors: Jiyao Xie, Long Zhang
abstract: With the widespread deployment of large-scale antenna arrays and high-frequency millimeter waves in 6G-enabled Internet of Things (IoT), simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) systems can now operate effectively in the near-field region. Additionally, the rapid growth in data traffic and the increasing number of connected terminals often result in spectrum scarcity. To address this challenge, this paper investigates a near-field Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA)-SWIPT system employing dynamic metasurface antennas (DMAs), with the objective of maximizing downlink wireless power transfer efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed nearfield NOMA-SWIPT system not only ensures user fairness but also achieves approximately a 1.16 times improvement in energy transfer performance compared to conventional near-field SWIPT systems.

title: Ingenious Frequency and PRF Agile Waveform Design for Accurate Motion Compensation and Efficient Coherent Accumulation
authors: Shu Liu, Endi Zhu, Jiadong Wang, Yachao Li, Qi Wang, Yang Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: Frequency agile waveforms have been widely used to improve radar's anti-jamming performance. However, such waveforms induce initial phase jitter and disrupt signal coherence, which escalates the problem of the target motion compensation and signal processing computational cost. To overcome this challenge, this paper proposes a novel method for designing ingenious frequency and pulse repetition frequency (PRF) joint agile waveforms that integrates target motion compensation, jitter initial phase compensation, and efficient coherent accumulation. First, the frequency and PRF of each group are ingeniously designed to preserve coherent echo signals, enabling the minimum image entropy algorithm to be introduced for target velocity estimation and achieve target motion compensation. Thanks to the identical frequency set of each pulse group, an inter-group cofrequency echo phase cancellation method is proposed to achieve precise compensation for initial phase jitter. Finally, a linear fitting method across pulse phases is proposed to achieve target Doppler uniformization, facilitating efficient target accumulation by the FFT algorithm. Simulation experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed waveform and processing method for motion compensation and coherent processing for targets.

title: Robust and Intelligent Multipath QUIC Transmission in Large-Scale LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Mengyang Zhang, Xiaoyu Liu, Xin Zhang, Yu Sun, Ting Ma, Haibo Zhou
abstract: With the advancement of low-earth orbit (LEO) satellite technologies, the Large-Scale LEO Satellite Networks (LSLSNs) have become the cornerstone of next-generation wireless communication, delivering global coverage with low latency and massive throughput. However, the LSLSNs operate in an open space environment, where the effects of space environmental factors such as electromagnetic radiation, thermal conditions and solar flares can easily lead to regional correlated damage for satellite nodes, severely degrading network performance. To ensure stable and robust transmission, we propose a Robust and Intelligent Multipath QUIC Transmission (RIMT) method in LSLSNs. The RIMT method is deployed in multi-domain based satellite networks leveraging distributed Software-Defined Networking (SDN) technology, where satellites are divided into various autonomous domains managed by a local SDN controller for high efficiency and flexible management. To address regional correlated damage, RIMT employs pre-computed backup flows to seamlessly switch from compromised flows. Additionally, we introduce an innovative congestion control algorithm designed to maintain stable data transmission during the route switching process. We implement RIMT in the Kuiper K3 shell network, experiments show that RIMT can achieve more enhanced performance than other mechanisms.

title: Emerging Requirements for AI and Edge Computing in Cyber-Physical Production Systems
authors: Rui Pinto, Gil Gonçalves
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: As Cyber-Physical Production Systems (CPPS) and the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) evolve, the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Edge Computing is enabling more responsive, autonomous, and intelligent industrial operations. However, this shift introduces a set of emerging requirements that traditional CPPS architectures are not equipped to address. This paper presents a structured requirement analysis for AI- and Edge-enabled CPPS in industrial contexts. The analysis is organized into three domains: (i) AI/ML-specific requirements, (ii) Edge Computing requirements, and (iii) Edge analytics requirements. Each requirement is characterized across dimensions such as reliability, adaptability, and resource intensity, and illustrated through realistic industrial scenarios. Grounded in insights from multiple collaborative R&D projects, the framework captures technical and operational needs, offering a practical reference for designing and deploying next-generation CPPS in smart manufacturing and beyond.

title: A Machine Vision-Based Approach for Dispensing Position Acquisition
authors: Tianlei Wang, Yixiang Mo, Jingnan Fang, Zeyuan Fei, Zhu Wang, Sicheng Wan, Wanyang Chen, Bing Chen, Kangli Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of inaccurate dispensing positioning caused by angular deviation in the placement of PCB workpieces. An innovative dispensing localization method based on Blob analysis and template matching is proposed. First, Blob analysis is performed on the PCB workpiece to generate a binary image containing all dispensing points. A highly reliable positioning template is then obtained using template matching. Subsequently, the coordinates of each dispensing point within the template are mapped to their corresponding locations on a new PCB workpiece via an affine transformation. The key advantage of the proposed method is its ability to acquire a comprehensive and effective positioning template in a single operation, which is then used to locate dispensing positions on PCBs with angular deviations. Simulation experiments demonstrate that even when the acquired PCB workpiece exhibits a certain degree of angular deviation, the method maintains a positioning error below 0.1%. Therefore, the proposed approach provides a practical and efficient solution for achieving high-precision and high-efficiency PCB dispensing processes. Simulation results demonstrate the method's strong capability in correcting positional and angular misalignments. While initial validation is conducted under controlled conditions, the proposed approach presents a promising and efficient solution framework for high-precision PCB dispensing, laying the groundwork for future validation in real-world industrial settings.

title: Air Quality Sensors for Energy-saving and Self-diagnostics of a Local Exhaust Ventilation System with Self-powered Airflow Controller
authors: Zheng Jun Chew, Latifah Munirah Kamarudin, Ammar Zakaria, Syed Muhammad Mamduh Syed Zakaria, Balreddy Kothakapu, Roger Watson, Clive Bates
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Air quality (AQ) is crucial in the industry for financial as well as health and safety reasons. Thus, it is imperative to monitor and control workspace AQ. This paper proposed the integration of a smart AQ sensor system with self-powered autonomous airflow controllers (AACs) in a local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system. The AQ sensor system is integrated with artificial intelligence (AI) to improve sensing performance and reliability. The airflow energy harvester of the AAC could provide a local power source to meet the energy demand for sensing and AI. Sensor readings can be used to set appropriate airflow velocities for effective pollutant removal with optimized energy consumption of the LEV system. High volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and particulate matter (PM) levels after a long period of operation could be a sign of a faulty system. This improves the efficiency, resilience, and reliability of the LEV system as well as worker health and safety.

title: Children Presence Detection System in Vehicles via Wi-Fi Devices
authors: Zhen Chen, Hancheng Guo, Xiuyin Zhang
abstract: Safety incidents caused by children trapped in vehicles are a serious global problem. Existing solutions for child presence detection (CPD) are limited by specialized hardware or detection delays that exceed safety standards. To address this problem, this study proposes an innovative system to detect the presence of a child trapped in a car using channel state information (CSI), analyzing the effect of motion on CSI in subcarrier dimension through modeling and introducing new metrics to quantify environmental changes. The system is implemented using a commercial Wi-Fi chipset and tested in a real vehicle environment using data collected from eight people of different ages. Experimental results show that we achieved 99.19% detection accuracy within a 1-second time window at a low sampling rate of 20 Hz. This result represents a significant advancement in detection latency for CPD systems and lays the groundwork for widespread adoption of CPD systems based on Wi-Fi devices.

title: React-based Web Aplication Performance Optimization Using Code Splitting and Lazy Loading
authors: Tegar Fadillah Zanestri, Indra Lukmana Sardi, Kusuma Ayu Laksitowening
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computing and Applied Informatics (ICCAI)
abstract: This study aims to enhance the performance of a React-based web application that utilizes Client-Side Rendering (CSR) by applying two optimization techniques: code splitting and lazy loading. The main issue addressed is the low Lighthouse performance scores, which indicate slow initial loading times and large JavaScript bundle sizes, especially on pages with complex visual elements. To address these challenges, the research adopts a structured methodology consisting of initial performance analysis, identification of performance bottlenecks, implementation of modular loading strategies, and post-optimization testing. Development was conducted using Visual Studio Code, and performance evaluation was carried out with Google Lighthouse, Webpack Bundle Analyzer, and browser developer tools. The application developed for this study includes several core pages such as Login, Data Analysis, Data Account, Data Income, and Data Menu. The results demonstrate significant improvements: over 80% reduction in bundle size, up to 80.66% faster loading times, and performance score increases ranging from 19% to 70.8% across key metrics including First Contentful Paint (FCP), Largest Contentful Paint (LCP), Total Blocking Time (TBT), and Speed Index. These findings confirm that modular and on-demand loading strategies can effectively enhance the responsiveness and efficiency of CSR-based web applications. This research contributes practical insights for front-end performance optimization and offers a scalable solution applicable to modern web development practices.

title: Performance Analysis of RSRP Measurement for Low Power Synchronization Signal
authors: Xiuju Lv, Congxi Liu, Hang Long
abstract: Low-power wake-up signal (LP-WUS) serves as a critical technology addressing the energy efficiency requirements of Internet of things (IoT) devices. LP-WUS adopts the on-off keying (OOK) modulation scheme to implement device wake-up functionality, which achieves substantial energy consumption reduction. Furthermore, 3GPP has introduced a novel low-power synchronization signal (LP-SS) which ensures that wake-up receiver (WUR) can determine the start timing of LP-WUS coded bits. This periodic reference signal is also applicable for signal measurement to detect channel quality. The measurement method current employs the ON-OFF characteristics of sequences to estimate signal power and noise power. Under fading channels, the measurement performance of LP-SS exhibits a limitation, which has nothing to do with the measurement methods. Meanwhile, timing offset in non-coherent detection receivers also affects measurement performance. In this paper we analyze the impacts of fading and timing offset on measurement performance and derive the theoretical results of measurement errors. Meanwhile we conduct simulation analysis to verify the deviation between theoretical values and practical results. It demonstrates that timing offset causes measurement range shift rather than overall expansion, and that increasing average samples provides additional gains. These findings establish theoretical foundations for enhancing the performance of measurement methodologies.

title: Segmentation-Aided Detection and Classification of Broken Rice Using Mask R-CNN
authors: Mengya Hu, Lifeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: In order to improve the accuracy and efficiency of broken rice detection and classification, this paper proposes a mask R-CNN-based method for broken rice detection and classification. Using the publicly available broken rice image dataset and self-collected broken rice images to train the model, and making modifications to the model structure, complete rice grains and broken rice can be accurately recognized and segmented. On the basis of GBT1354-2018 and ISO 7301:2021 standards, the ratio of the projected area of broken rice to whole rice in the image is calculated, which effectively complements the traditional length-based classification method, and a finer classification standard is established by dividing rice into seven categories, including complete rice grains, more complete rice grains, broken rice, large broken rice, medium broken rice, small broken rice, and crumbs; experimental results show that the method's segmentation accuracy reaches 84.93%, classification accuracy reaches 99.5%, and the error rate between the model-predicted area and the actual mask area is 2.3%. This study provides a new classification standard and testing method for the detection and classification of broken rice and provides a scientific basis for the comprehensive utilization of broken rice.

title: Calibration method of MIMU two-axis turntable considering G-sensitivity error
authors: P. Lyu, G. Yan, X. Yang, X. Duan
abstract: When MEMS gyroscopes operate in scenarios where the applied specific force is constantly changing, like Satcom on the move(SOTM) and Electro-optical Pod, the gyroscope's G-sensitivity error will cause bias changes. If this bias change cannot be compensated for, it will lead to rapid attitude divergence. Therefore, G-sensitivity error should be calibrated before using the device. For the G-sensitivity error calibration problem of MEMS gyroscopes, a Calibration method of MIMU two-axis turntable considering G-sensitivity error is proposed. The G-sensitivity error model is added to the traditional gyroscope device model. Calibrate the gyroscope's constant bias and G sensitivity error using static data, and calibrate the gyroscope's scale error matrix and constant bias residual error using dynamic data. Corresponding simulation experiment, calibration experiment, and gravity reversal experiment are conducted separately. The experiment results show that the proposed calibration method is effective. The simulation experiment result shows that the proposed calibration method can separate the G-sensitivity error from the gyroscope device error. In the calibration experiment of this paper shows that the pure inertial navigation update reduces the eastern misalignment angle by 48.94%, the northward misalignment angle by 25.61%, and the upward misalignment angle by 81.54%. The results of gravity invert experiment shows that gyroscope x-axis bias standard deviation under specific force variation reduced by 54.60%, y-axis reduced by 13.44%, z-axis reduced by 34.51%.

title: Performance Analysis of BDS Single-Epoch Triple-Frequency Vehicle-Borne RTK under Complex Urban Scenarios
authors: Tuan Li, Xiangdong Chen, Yuhao Xiao, Zhigang Wang, Ning Fu, Jun Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Industrial Informatics (INDIN)
abstract: Vehicle-borne positioning in urban environments is a crucial application scenario of the BeiDou Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) technique. However, its performance is often affected by signal interruptions and ambiguity resolution failures. The integration of BeiDou-3 (BDS-3) and BeiDou-2 (BDS-2) will significantly increase the number of available satellites with improved ambiguity resolution, thereby enhancing high-precision positioning performance in complex urban environments. In this work, a vehicle-borne experiment with collected triple-frequency observations from BDS-2 and BDS-3 satellites were utilized to evaluate the ambiguity resolution and positioning performance of single-epoch triple-frequency RTK positioning in urban environments. The results indicate that in complex urban environments, the extra-wide-lane ambiguity of certain satellites cannot be correctly resolved by the integer rounding methods. The centimeter-level positional availability of BDS-2 alone is relatively low, whereas the ambiguity resolution success rate and centimeter-level positional availability are significantly improved when BDS-2 and BDS-3 signals are integrated.

title: Deep Learning Based Surface Defect Detection of Ceramic Cores
authors: Tianlei Wang, Xinyao Chen, Jingnan Fang, Sicheng Wan, Yuan Peng, Zhu Wang, Zeyuan Fei, Bing Chen, Kangli Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronic Information, Computer and Aerospace Remote Sensing (EICARS)
abstract: The ceramic valve core is widely used in industry due to its wear resistance, corrosion resistance, and hightemperature resistance. However, its high hardness and brittleness make it prone to damage and cracks during processing, affecting the product's appearance, safety, and service life. Therefore, accurate and efficient surface defect detection is crucial. Although existing detection methods have made some progress, there are still shortcomings in detection speed, computational resource consumption, and hyperparameter tuning. To address these issues, this paper proposes a surface defect detection method for ceramic valve cores based on a lightweight object detection network. The method employs MobileNetV3 to construct a multi-scale feature pyramid, incorporates an anchor-free region proposal network that generates candidate boxes by directly predicting object centers and offsets to achieve real-time defect detection. Additionally, a channel attention mechanism is used to improve classification accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that this method offers high detection accuracy and low computational resource consumption, making it suitable for defect detection tasks in industrial production. It effectively resolves the challenges of traditional methods in handling the diversity of defects and multiscale characteristics in complex production environments.

title: Refining Reselection Counter Configuration for Safety and Fairness in 5G NR V2X
authors: Hyungjoon Shin, Hyogon Kim
abstract: For vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) safety communication in 3GPP New Radio (NR) Sidelink Mode 2, each vehicle must autonomously select periodic radio resource by using Sensing-based Semi-Persistent Scheduling (SB-SPS) algorithm. SB-SPS helps avoid packet collisions through determining whether a particular resource among potential candidates will be used by other vehicle’s transmission. In 3GPP Release 16, all packet transmission (Tx) periods below 100 ms were newly allowed to support more delay-critical safety applications. Unfortunately, an undesirable artifact of the current specification is that vehicles operating with different Tx periods can experience excessive and unfair successive collision event lengths. This may cause some vehicles to suffer longer average successive collision durations just by picking a "wrong" resource reservation period (RRP). To address this issue, we propose a revision to the current specification for fair resource occupancy time for all vehicles irrespective of RRPs. Through analysis and simulation, it is shown to resolve the unfair and inordinate collision episode lengths issue while scarcely sacrificing packet delivery performance compared to the current specification.

title: Power Spectrum Analysis-Based Counterfeit Screening: A Hardware Comparison
authors: Devon R. Richman, Connor P. Dempsey, Steven J. Dourmaskin, Michael H. Azarian, Diganta Das
publish: 2025 IEEE Physical Assurance and Inspection of Electronics (PAINE)
abstract: This study provides a comparative evaluation of the effectiveness of side-channel power spectrum analysis (PSA) for counterfeit microelectronic component detection using the Chiplytics PSA system and benchtop test and measurement equipment. Independent testing was performed by the University of Maryland's CALCE laboratory and Chiplytics using three signal voltage levels applied to three sets of functionally identical logic gate parts. Data was analyzed using principal component analysis and K-means clustering. The K-means fit was assessed based on the clustering accuracy and the silhouette score. The Chiplytics PSA system consistently achieved higher clustering accuracy than the benchtop equipment, with Chiplytics achieving 100% accuracy for all tested voltages. Similarly, the Chiplytics PSA system consistently demonstrated a silhouette score <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>0.6$</tex> independent of test site, compared to the benchtop equipment, which only achieved a silhouette score <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>0.6$</tex> for a single measurement setup across the two test sites. The benchtop equipment yielded inconsistent results across teams, underscoring the impact of setup variability. The results indicate that a standalone PSA measurement system provides improved counterfeit detection capabilities over traditional benchtop equipment configurations.

title: Lightweight Digital Twin Enabled Vehicle Control for Mixed-Autonomy Traffic
authors: Xiwen Liao, Supeng Leng, Ke Zhang, Yao Sun, Muhammad Ali Imran
abstract: With Internet of Vehicles and advanced onboard computing, connected autonomous vehicles (CAVs) can interact and process driving data in real time, enhancing safety and improving road efficiency. However, in mixed-autonomy traffic, the unpredictability of human-driven vehicles (HDVs) poses significant challenges for CAV control. Moreover, existing cooperative control methods often assume seamless real-time information sharing, leading to excessive communication demands that strain limited transmission resources. To address these issues, we propose a lightweight Digital Twin (DT) framework that models the traffic environment and surrounding vehicle behaviors to reduce uncertainty in CAV decision-making. The framework employs an attention-based multi-agent deep reinforcement learning method, enabling each CAV to dynamically adjust its communication frequency with neighboring vehicles according to the significance of their observations for its driving control decisions. Asynchronous updates in the DT space allow CAVs to expand their situational awareness, enabling lightweight coordination that mitigates HDV disturbances and fosters swarm intelligence. Simulations show our scheme improves traffic stability and achieves 30% faster high-speed flow than baselines, while maintaining strong performance under low bandwidth.

title: Anti-jamming in Frequency-hopping Communication Systems via Reinforced Continual Learning
authors: Jingyu Zhao, Hongcheng Tan, Jianquan Wang, Peng Wei, Sa Xiao, Wanbin Tang
abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has emerged as a promising anti-jamming solution in frequency-hopping (FH) communication systems, owing to its dynamic anti-jamming capability independent of FH patterns. Nevertheless, conventional RL-based methods may require extensive retraining when previously encountered jamming signals reappear after a long period because of the obliviousness of RL. To address this issue, this paper proposes a memory-driven anti-jamming approach for FH communications. Inspired by reinforced continual learning (RCL), the proposed approach employs an adaptive expansion mechanism of sub-deep neural networks to efficiently capture and retain jamming patterns. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach can make more rapid anti-jamming decisions compared to conventional methods when encountering previously observed jamming patterns.

title: Rate Optimization in Distributed RIS Aided MIMO System Using Soft Actor-Critic Method of DRL
authors: Ayush B. Patel, Abhishek Jindal
abstract: We consider a distributed reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) enabled MIMO system with a transmitter and a receiver. In this work, we find the optimal precoding matrix at the transmitter and the optimal phase shifts at the multiple RISs, under a transmit power constraint. The problem under consideration is non-convex, and in the recent literature, deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based methods have shown promising results in such scenarios. Our solution is particularly based on the soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm of DRL. Our innovative Markov Decision Process (MDP) formulation for the problem leads to better rate compared with the prevalent formulations. Our simulation results show that SAC can improve the rate considerably starting from a random value. For fair comparison, we consider deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) and alternating optimization (AO) as benchmarks. Our contribution also includes a new way of handling each episode which leads to stable training.
